item.title: Black Myth: Wukong Is More Than a Journey to the West Adaptation
item.description:
The following contains spoilers for Black Myth: Wukong .

While it first appeared as though Game Science's Black Myth: Wukong would put players in direct control of Sun Wukong, the Monkey King from the 16th-century Chinese novel Journey to the West , the action RPG is set some time after the events of the novel. Ultimately, this means that Black Myth: Wukong is separated enough from Journey to the West that it can attempt to establish its own identity as an original story, as opposed to being a direct adaption of the novel. As a result, rather than playing through Black Myth: Wukong as Sun Wukong himself, players experience a reimagining of the world brought to life by Journey to the West through the eyes of a humble monkey simply referred to as the "Destined One" — an almost identical physical copy of Sun Wukong.

In many ways, Black Myth: Wukong could be considered a sequel to Journey to the West , as it makes regular past-tense references to the original story throughout its own roughly 30-hour narrative. However, Journey to the West is more the bones of Black Myth: Wukong than the muscles, with the novel essentially only serving as the foundation for the moving story and enchanting world Game Science has crafted here. It certainly doesn't shy away from including some of the most notable characters from Journey to the West — though many of them have been reconceptualized for the game — and its heavy reliance on Eastern mythology helps to fill in any gaps left in the wake of its semi-adaptive format.

Some of Black Myth: Wukong's Major Characters and Locations Are Pulled Directly From Journey to the West

While the Destined One is an original character created specifically for Black Myth: Wukong , many of the game's other major characters are almost explicit copies of those from Journey to the West . As the game's story takes place five centuries after the events of the novel, these characters help maintain the game's connection to its "past" and, in turn, give substance to its present. The major boss of Black Myth: Wukong 's first chapter, for instance, is the Black Wind King, who is based on the Black Wind Demon from Journey to the West . Both the Black Wind King and the Black Wind Demon wield a Black Tassel Spear, can transform into a ferocious black bear, and serve as the guardian of Black Wind Mountain. The Black Wind King is also the first character to confirm Black Myth: Wukong 's place in Journey to the West 's timeline when he mentions it has been 500 years since his last encounter with Sun Wukong.

One of Black Myth: Wukong 's most complex and developed characters is Bajie, a major character in Journey to the West who now fills the role of partner, mentor, and guide to the Destined One throughout most of the game's story. In the novel, Bajie is characterized by his laziness to some degree, but his respectful and soft-hearted side is often revealed in his love for Sun Wukong, whom he affectionately refers to as "brother." His relationship is best defined as warm, and it's easy for readers to endear themselves to him as a result. In Black Myth: Wukong , on the other hand, Bajie's most prominent characteristics are his arrogance and recklessness. However, his unbridled commitment to the game's protagonist often exposes the same tenderness of the character he is based on, as he can't help but see his old friend when he looks at the Destined One. The unifying element among these takes on Bajie is how likeabe he truly is.

The game also features many of the same locations from Journey to the West , though they have been meticulously crafted from the ground up to provide plenty of room for exploration and Black Myth: Wukong 's countless bosses. Journey to the West locations like Black Wind Mountain, Yellow Wind Ridge, the Flaming Mountains, and Mount Huaguo are all explorable locations in Black Myth: Wukong . However, they have been designed to reflect time-driven change and their current role in a brand-new story centuries ahead of the novel. This helps Black Myth: Wukong to set itself apart from Journey to the West as a standalone experience.

Black Myth: Wukong Includes Original Characters and Evolved Locations to Define Itself

Black Myth: Wukong may dig its roots into Journey to the West , but the significant time gap between the two stories doesn't require the game to remain true to every single element of its source material. This ultimately grants some leeway for Game Science to include characters not found in Journey to the West , while still honoring its nature as an Eastern mythology-inspired story. Black Myth: Wukong therefore introduces new characters — primarily enemies — not originally found in Journey to the West that are largely inspired by Eastern mythology, in addition to new and revised locations from the novel to reflect the passage of time.

Journey to the West is a pantheon of celestial beings, deities, and mythological creatures known as Yaoguai, and Black Myth: Wukong is perhaps even more so with its inclusion of Yaoguai not found in the novel. The Destined One encounters dozens of "lesser" Yaoguai in Black Myth: Wukong that we haven't see in Journey to the West , including the Croaky, the Crow Diviner, the Tenner, and the Pitstone, Poisestone, and Palestone. Some of Black Myth: Wukong 's bosses we also have not seen in Journey to the West , though almost every major boss is.

Black Myth: Wukong introduces new characters — primarily enemies — not originally found in Journey to the West that are largely inspired by Eastern mythology, in addition to new and revised locations from the novel to reflect the passage of time.

As far as locations go, most of those that players can travel to in Black Myth: Wukong are mentioned in Journey to the West . Others, like Crouching Tiger Temple, Turtle Island, Mirrormere, and the Pagoda Realm, are not — although the novel does include various pagoda structures. This is just another way that Black Myth: Wukong sets itself apart from Journey to the West to give players an experience they wouldn't even be able to get from the 16th-century novel the game is based on.

Black Myth: Wukong certainly relies on the story, characters, and locations of Journey to the West to establish context for the Destined One's journey. At the same time, this is a story that takes some time after the events of Journey to the West , so Game Science has ensured that it feels like a brand-new story by including new creatures based on Eastern mythology and new locations never mentioned in the book. Getting to explore these locations, undertake quests, and otherwise appreciate the beauty of Black Myth: Wukong will go a long way - beyond its boss fights. After all, Black Myth: Wukong is not a boss rush - it's a journey through a Chinese mythology and Journey to the West -inspired world. Its emphasis on original elements, engaging worldbuilding, and beautiful vistas ensures that even those unfamiliar with Journey to the West should be able to appreciate Black Myth: Wukong as an original adventure.

item.title: Zenless Zone Zero: Quirky Girl Inquiry Guide
item.description:
Quick Links

  • The Quirky Girl Inquiry Answer In Zenless Zone Zero
  • How To Get The Never Overtime Videotape In ZZZ

Fighting Ethereals in the Hollow is not the only thing Proxies of Zenless Zone Zero are good at. They also have their main business — the Random Play Video Store, which requires much of their attention, as it contributes to paying most of their bills. As the only Video Store available down Sixth Street, all customers in New Eridu visit the store for a variety of things.

The Quirky Girl is one of them, and just like her name suggests, she’s a little eccentric in her tastes. She’s looking for a videotape recommendation, and where else better to get one than the Random Play video store? She’ll probably pop up for most Zenless Zone Zero players when they reach Video Store Level 6 . So, keep an eye out for her and make sure she gets the correct tape.

The Quirky Girl Inquiry Answer In Zenless Zone Zero

The Quirky Girl in ZZZ is looking for something out of the box because she plans to open up a paranormal club . She’s looking for inspiration, and her only hope is a fantasy movie with some ‘wacky’ theatrics. The request is pretty simple, and when you filter out the options from the genre list, you’ll be left with two movies.

Both movies may seem to work due to their descriptions, but ZZZ loves to trick their players. The videotape description that sounds most like the one requested often doesn’t end up being the correct one. Never Overtime is the correct answer for the Quirky Girl . This can easily confuse players because its description is the complete opposite of a fantasy movie.

  • The Never Overtime videotape is a Level 3 one, and that is the reason why it works better to satisfy the Quirky Girl’s expectations.

How To Get The Never Overtime Videotape In ZZZ

The Never Overtime videotape is at Level 3 and is only obtainable after completing Nekomata’s Agent Story . Nekomata’s Agent Story — Cat and Mouse Game — is unlocked during Chapter 2 - Intermission, and each sub-story is unlocked at the corresponding Inter-Knot levels (27 & 28). Players can only gain access to the videotape after completing all the sub-stories.

The videotape will be automatically added to your list and when the Quirky Girl comes in; just recommend it to her to receive the awards. Players will receive 12,500 Dennies when giving her the correct videotape.

Unfortunately, there is no grand prize other than that, but successfully recommending the correct videotape will help raise customer satisfaction . This can aid in raising your Random Play Video Store level and invite more NPCs to come to you for recommendations. This raises customer trust and influences your business positively. Some of the NPC recommendations are a little tough, so make it a point to keep an eye out and choose the right videotape.

item.title: Zenless Zone Zero - Hapless Man Inquiry (Tragedy Videotape)
item.description:
Quick Links

  • The Hapless Man Inquiry Answer In ZZZ
  • How To Get The Black Tales Videotape In ZZZ

Aside from fighting enemies in the Hollow and saving the city of New Eridu from its constant threats, Proxies in Zenless Zone Zero have the most chilled-out main job. They run the Random Play Video Store, which also works as a home base for all their Hollow missions. The video store is run by the Proxies and is Sixth Street's go-to spot when looking for a decent movie to kick back and relax with.

During the day, various customers come and go, purchasing various movies to indulge in. Proxies in Zenless Zone Zero can open the store every day and simply wait for the extra money to flow in. Additionally, they’ll also come across some NPCs who come seeking recommendations for videotapes to watch. The Hapless Man who is looking for a Tragedy Videotape is one of them.

The Hapless Man Inquiry Answer In ZZZ

The Hapless Man’s Inquiry is pretty simple in comparison to the other NPCs that ask for a recommendation. This is because he’s already been through a lot and seems to be unconcerned with explaining himself. He’s pretty down on his luck with life and all he wants is a Tragedy movie to watch. He doesn’t want to feel like he’s the only one feeling miserable and this hint makes things a whole lot easier for players.

The correct answer for the Hapless Man is the Black Tales Videotape . You can filter your video genre to Tragic and two options will come up. Black Tales and Encore - however, Encore is not the correct one, and it will not give you any rewards. Black Tales works better because it’s a Level 3 videotape, whereas Encore is just Level 2. The Hapless Man will just be dissatisfied with the recommendation and you’ll have to wait awhile to see him again.

How To Get The Black Tales Videotape In ZZZ

The Black Tales videotape is only available after reaching Video Store Level 5 and Inter-Knot Level 35 . You’ll need to speak to Anna at Random Play and only then will the video be added to your list. It hasn’t been confirmed whether she will immediately give it to you, but it’s a must to reach the specific levels.

Once the Hapless Man is at the counter and you have obtained the videotape, simply recommend it to him and wait for the yellow interaction bubble. Speak to him immediately and he’ll thank you for the recommendation. You’ll receive 12, 500 Dennies and unfortunately not anything else. However, getting this right will help players build the Video Store's trust and reputation with its customers. Players can then look forward to more NPCs entering the Video Store and asking for more recommendations, helping the business flourish.

item.title: WoW SoD: Best Phase 4 Consumables For Every Class
item.description:
Now that Phase 4 of Classic WoW's Season of Discovery is in full swing, players have reached the traditional level 60 cap and are exploring the endgame dungeons and raids, many of which have new features. What hasn't changed is the list of consumables that players have to take with them to raids, and these handy but temporary items can also be helpful in some of the endgame dungeons.

Players should choose consumables according to their raid role and the strengths of their class. Many of the consumables from Phase 3 are still useful in max-level raids, so players can stock the same items along with some other useful selections.

This is so important that the leaders of the raid often designate one person as their Alchemist, cook, fisher, or Herbalist since most of the best consumables are crafted.

General Consumes For Everyone

No Matter The Class Or Role, Don't Raid Without Them

  • Certain kinds of food and drink have bonuses that stack with flasks, elixirs, and potions

The following consumables are from previous phases, with two notable exceptions, but they can still be useful in raids for any class.

  • Enchanted Sigil: Flowing Waters. A new Phase 4 buff is available from those who have a Revered reputation with the Hydrexian Waterlords and at least 290 in Enchanting, the source of this raid-wide consumable is an Enchanting spell. It gives everyone in the raid a +30 to damage and healing spells and attack power.
  • Might of Stormwind. A new Phase 4 world buff for Alliance players that's the equivalent of the Horde's Rallying Cry of the Dragonslayer, it gives +15 to attack speed and adds 300 to the character's health.
  • Cooking Recipes. Runn Tum Tuber Surprise, Nightfin Soup, Grilled Squid, and other useful dishes are all crafted food items that are useful in raids and almost any class can use them. Rum Tum Tuber Surprise is the most difficult to find and make. The recipe only drops from Pusllian, one of the bosses in Dire Maul, and the rubers are only found in Razorfen Crawl.
  • Enriched Mana Biscuits. Available to those who have a Friendly reputation with the Argent Dawn, this is a cheap, high-level food from Phase 3 that restores both health and mana. Get to Honored and other more powerful consumables are available, such as Blessed Sunfruit.
  • Demonic Runes. These are a rare drop from demons and satyrs in both the open world and various dungeons. They restore mana, but at the cost of health, and are useful to any class that uses mana except Warlocks who already have the Life Tap ability.
  • The Winterspring Doctor. If you bring Witch Doctor Mau'ari in Wintersrping trades a few E'kos, he'll turn them into powerful Jujus that provide better elemental resistance and improved attack and spell power. These are often more powerful than the equivalent potion or elixir.

Raid Consumes By Class And Role

Prepare For Raids With Mage Healers And Warlock Tanks

  • A wide variety of party roles and compositions are possible depending on gear, talent points, and runes. All of the following recommendations will stack with the World Buffs and the standard Mage intellect buff.

Druid

Role

Best Consumes

Feral DPS

  • Catnip
  • Flask of Supreme Power
  • Elixir of the Mongoose
  • Grilled Squid
  • Free Action Potion

Balance DPS

  • Flask of Supreme Power
  • Wizard Oil
  • Mageblood Potion
  • Cerebral Cortex Compoind
  • Runn Tum Tuber Surprise or Nightfun Soup

Healer

  • Flask of Distilled Wisdom
  • Elixir of Fortitude or Elixir of Defense
  • Mighty Troll's Blood Potion
  • Cerebral Cortex Compound
  • Nightfin Soup

Tank

  • Elixir of Giants or Elixir of the Mongoose
  • Greater Stoneshield Potion
  • Winterfall Firewater
  • Grilled Squid or Smoked Desert Dumplings
  • Rumsey Rum Black Label

Hunter

Role

Best Consumes

Melee DPS

  • Greater Nature/Shadow/Fire/Arcane Protection Potion
  • Elixir of the Mongoose
  • Atal'ai Mojo of War
  • Grilled Squid
  • Winterfall Firewater
  • Oil of Immolation

Ranged DPS

  • Elixir of the Mongoose
  • Nightfin Soup or Grilled Squid
  • Atal'ai Mojo of War
  • Wizard Oil
  • Demonic Runes

Mage

Role

Best Consumes

Healer / DPS

  • Flask of Supreme Power
  • Greater Arcane Elixir or Elixir of Firepower
  • Wizard Oil
  • Nightfin Soup or Runn Tum Tuber Suprise
  • Mageblood Potion
  • Cerebral Cortex Compound
  • Mildly Irradiated Rejuvenation Potion (Alchemists only)

Paladin

Best Consumes

Healer

  • Flask of Distilled Wisdom
  • Mageblood Potion
  • Demonic Runes
  • Cerebral Cortex Compound
  • Nightfin Soup
  • Wizard Oil

DPS

  • Flask of the Titans
  • Blessed Sunfruit
  • Juju Power or Elixir of the Giants
  • Grilled Squid or Nightfin Soup
  • R.O.I.D.S.
  • Winterfall Firewater

Tank

  • Flask of Supreme Power
  • Greater Stoneshield Potion
  • Elixir of Fortitude
  • Rumsey Rum Black Label
  • Grilled Squid

Priest

Role

Best Consumes

Healer

  • Flask of Distilled Wisdom
  • Wizard Oil
  • Elixir of Greater Defense
  • Greater Arcane Elixir
  • Nightfin Soup

DPS

  • Cerebral Cortex Compound

Rogue

item.title: Future FromSoftware Games Should Be More Like Sekiro and Less Like Elden Ring With One Enemy Type
item.description:
Highlights

  • Elden Ring elevates FromSoftware's action-RPG formula, offering a vast open world with exciting bosses and loot.
  • While Elden Ring's dragon bosses are epic, some may find the fights repetitive due to similar movesets.
  • To create the ideal dragon boss fight, FromSoftware should combine the scale of Sekiro with the gameplay of Elden Ring.

With each subsequent game under its belt, FromSoftware continues to improve upon its now-beloved action-RPG formula. From more experimental boss designs in Dark Souls 2 , to the introduction of trick weapons in Bloodborne , to the grander scale and scope of Dark Souls 3 's story, each and every FromSoftware game has tried to take the formula at least one step further, and that's certainly the case with Elden Ring .

By far FromSoftware's most ambitious title to date, Elden Ring brings the developer's action-RPG formula to a gigantic open-world setting and packs that world with exciting bosses, mysterious dungeons, and rewarding loot. By all accounts, Elden Ring is a massive step forward for FromSoftware's formula, but there are one or two things past games do slightly better, and Sekiro 's approach to dragon bosses could arguably be one of those.

Future FromSoftware Games Should Use Sekiro's Dragon Boss Blueprint Over Elden Ring's

Elden Ring's Dragon Bosses Are Epic But Repetitive

The first time players run into one of Elden Ring 's dragons is a pretty momentous occasion. More often than not, players' first dragon encounter will be with Elden Ring 's Flying Dragon Agheel, located near the starting area of Limgrave. This boss fight is suitably epic, with the dragon's moveset containing a variety of impressive sweeping attacks and flying maneuvers. But while Flying Dragon Agheel is a memorable boss fight, it quickly becomes just one of many.

Elden Ring features well over 10 dragons, with a handful more appearing in the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC. Though all of these dragons have different names and slightly different visual designs, many boast very similar movesets, albeit with a different elemental attack. These similar movesets eventually lead to some fairly repetitive fights, and after rolling credits on Elden Ring , some players will find that many of the game's dragon bosses have blended into one.

That being said, there are a handful of dragon boss fights in Elden Ring that stand ahead of the rest of the pack. Dragonlord Placidusax, Lichdragon Fortissax, and the most recent and impressive addition, Bayle the Dread all offer some of the best dragon boss fights in FromSoftware's catalog, with each one delivering impressive visuals, a bombastic score, and a distinct moveset.

Sekiro's Dragon Boss Feels Truly Special

Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice may only feature one dragon boss fight, but it's one of the most memorable in FromSoftware history. Located at the end of Fountainhead Palace, Sekiro 's Divine Dragon sits at the end of an enormous, otherworldly arena. After taking out some tree-like dragon minions, the Divine Dragon reveals itself in all its ethereal glory, wielding a large blue sword unlike any from the real world. Players need to avoid the dragon's sweeping attacks, ride its conjured winds high into the sky, and rain lightning down upon its head. It may be an easy fight, but it's a truly epic one that manages to capture the majesty and scale of a dragon fight in a way unlike any of FromSoft's games before it.

An Ideal FromSoftware Dragon Boss Fight Lies Somewhere In The Middle

If the next FromSoftware action-RPG is going to include a dragon boss fight, it should take a page out of both Elden Ring and Sekiro 's respective playbooks. The ideal FromSoftware dragon boss fight would capture the scale and elegance of such a fantastical creature, just as Sekiro 's Divine Dragon did, but it would also borrow the faster-paced gameplay of Elden Ring 's Bayle and Placidusax.
